MainHeading.P: Chuaigh an Ceann Comhairle i gceannas ar 2.30 p.m.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Before proceeding to questions I am sure Members would wish to be associated with me in extending a most warm welcome to the Governor General Designate of New Zealand, Sir Michael Hardie Boys, and his charming wife, Lady Mary, together with members of their entourage. I hope their visit to Ireland will be happy and successful and, on your behalf, I bid them a most hearty céad mile fáilte, a hundred thousand welcomes.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Meeting with UUP Delegation.

Qst.Quest: the matters for discussion at his meeting with the Unionist leader Mr. Trimble.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Taoiseach (Mr. G. Mitchell) Minister of State at the Department of the Taoiseach (Mr. G. Mitchell)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Taoiseach (Mr. G. Mitchell)
Speaker.P: A Government delegation, comprising the Taoiseach, the Tánaiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Social Welfare, had a very useful meeting yesterday with a UUP delegation led by the party leader, Mr. David Trimble, MP.
The discussions were open and frank and while conclusions were not reached, the meeting provided a better mutual understanding of our respective positions on the most effective way forward.

The exchanges focused on the relevant key issues to be addressed in the substantive phase of the all-party negotiations commencing on 10 June, including the arrangements for them. Yesterday's meeting between the Government and the UUP has helped to build on the progress already achieved in the intensive consultations with the Northern Ireland parties.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. O'Rourke Mrs. O'Rourke
Speaker.P: It is bizarre that the person who attended the meeting is sitting in silence while the person answering the question did not attend the meeting. Perhaps that is the way the Government is working these days. Why was there such emphasis on legislation about arms decommissioning?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: The Taoiseach offered to postpone this question until his return but the Deputy insisted on it being taken today.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. O'Rourke Mrs. O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I did not insist. I received a telephone call asking if I wished to have these questions answered and I said I did.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: There shall be no arguments now. Let us proceed with questions as arranged.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: The question of such legislation and other matters relating to decommissioning are under consideration and no decision has been taken by the Government. I refer the Deputy to paragraph 12 of the communiqué of 28 February.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. O'Rourke Mrs. O'Rourke
Speaker.P: While the communiqué is interesting. I am talking about the meeting held yesterday in Government Buildings. Irrespective of the Government's housekeeping arrangements, it is odd that the Tánaiste, who attended the meeting, is sitting in silence while the person speaking on the Government's behalf did not attend the meeting. That is out of order.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Repetition is a luxury we can ill afford at Question Time.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. McDowell Mr. M. McDowell
Speaker.P: What aspects of our legislation are under examination? Will the Minister of State indicate whether it is accepted at Government level that there are deficiencies in our legislation as regards decommissioning?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: The matter raised by the Deputy is addressed in paragraph 12 of the communiqué. It states that both Governments recognise that confidence building measures will be necessary and all participants would need to make clear at the beginning of the discussions their total and absolute commitment to the principles of democracy and nonviolence.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Martin Mr. Martin
Speaker.P: That is not a response to the question the Deputy asked.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: The matter raised by the Deputy is referred to in the communiqué.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Martin Mr. Martin
Speaker.P: It is not.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: The matter was touched on only briefly at the meeting and the Government has not made a decision on it. This issue is under consideration.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Let us not dwell unduly long on this question as we should not forget the time factor involved in dealing with questions to the Taoiseach.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: We are not delaying on the question but this matter is of primary importance. There is not another matter that is as important as the peace process to the people, and yesterday's meeting was crucial. In the briefing given after the meeting the Taoiseach placed great emphasis on the question of forthcoming legislation. Will the Minister of State emphasise what is involved? Is legislation being introduced? Is this another precondition for Sinn Féin's participation in the talks? Is the electoral process the only way to the table or will further preconditions be set?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: Many matters were discussed at yesterday's meeting but no decision was taken on legislation. The question of such legislation and other matters relating to decommissioning are under consideration. As the Deputy is aware, the Taoiseach and Tánaiste have done everything in their power not to set preconditions and to bring all parties to the talks. Yesterday's discussions were, in themselves, a major step forward in that regard.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. McDaid Dr. McDaid
Speaker.P: Did discussions take place on whether the Official Unionist Party would take part in the 10 June talks? In the event of this party not participating in the talks and of a ceasefire not being called until after 10 June, is it possible for the parties to resume talks at a later date?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: I cannot speak for Mr. Trimble or any of the UUP delegation but the Taoiseach and Tánaiste have stated on numerous occasions — this is also set out in the communiqué of 28 February — that the date of 10 June is fixed and firm. No one can be unclear about the Government's position on this matter.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. McDaid Dr. McDaid
Speaker.P: I asked what would happen in the event of a ceasefire not being called before 10 June.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Speaker.P: Was the elective process discussed at the meeting and, if not, when does the Government expect the process to take place given that the so-called proximity talks are nearing an end?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: The elective process was not discussed but the issues which were discussed drew attention to the three requirements in regard to the elective process set out in the Mitchell report: first, it would need to be broadly acceptable; second, it would need to have an appropriate mandate and, third, it would have to be within the three strand structure. The Taoiseach and the Tánaiste have set out the Government's position on these matters. The answer to the Deputy's question is “no”.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Speaker.P: To what question is that the answer? When will the elective process take place?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Order, please. I want to bring Question No. 1 to finality.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Speaker.P: The Minister is supposed to impart information, not withhold it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. McDowell Mr. M. McDowell
Speaker.P: Does the legislation in question concern either or both of the following matters: first, the empowerment of an international body to verify the decommissioning of weapons and, second, the granting of an amnesty or immunity from prosecution for those who might surrender their weapons?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: A decision has not been reached by the Government on the type of legislation, if any, to be introduced.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Speaker.P: Is the Minister of State telling the House the electoral process was not discussed?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: That is correct.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Speaker.P: Does he not find that strange?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: The whole process was not discussed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Speaker.P: In other words, there was no reference to the elections or referenda.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: There was a wide-ranging general discussion——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Speaker.P: But not on this matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: ——but not on the process.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Speaker.P: That is disgraceful.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: During my 23 years as a Member of the House this is the first time a Minister or Minister of State needed the benefit of notes from a civil servant when replying to questions. I am not commenting on the efficiency of the civil servant but I have not seen this happen in the House before.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: There should not be reference to civil servants.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: All Ministers and Ministers of State defend themselves——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Currie Mr. Currie
Speaker.P: The Deputy is being totally unfair.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: The Minister of State is responsible and there should not be reference to public servants.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: The civil servant is doing an excellent job but he should not be asked to do it during Question Time. It is totally wrong.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Currie Mr. Currie
Speaker.P: The Deputy is milking the situation for all the political advantage he can gain.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: Will the Minister of State agree with the views expressed in the editorial in last Monday's edition of the Irish News which was highly critical of the Taoiseach's speech at the Fine Gael Ard Fheis and which stated that a three strand approach is critical to a solution of the problems in the North and must not be jettisoned at the price of having tea with David Trimble and John Taylor?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: I was at the Ard Fheis and I assure the House that the Taoiseach made an excellent speech which was consistent with everything he has said to date on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: That is not the view of Nationalists in Northern Ireland. The Tánaiste should be ashamed of having allowed a Minister of State to reply to such serious questions.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Currie Mr. Currie
Speaker.P: The Deputy is being antiNationalist.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Martin Mr. Martin
Speaker.P: That is a ridiculous allegation and the Minister of State should withdraw it.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - NESC Reports.

Qst.Quest: the reports, if any, for which the National Economic and Social Council is waiting and which have been requested by the Government.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: The National Economic and Social Council is awaiting two reports in phase two of its work on output and employment, “Employment and Enterprise in the Irish Economy”. These reports are on: (i) Ireland's investment performance and (ii) competitive advantage on clusters in the Irish economy: a study of selected manufacturing and service activities. Consultants' reports on these subjects are expected in May 1996 and June 1996, respectively.

MainHeading.P: As the Taoiseach outlined in his response to a question by Deputy Ivor Callely last Wednesday, the Government has requested the NESC to look at three matters as follows: (i) it is proposed that the council should examine and take into account in its work on employment and enterprise in the Irish economy the recommendations of the OECD jobs study published in June 1994 and those of the EU White Papers, Growth, Competitiveness, Employment and Social Policy, taking account of the relevant components of the Government's new approach to industrial policy set out in response to the Moriarty Task Force on the implementation of the Culliton report and indicate to what extent, and how, they should be implemented in Ireland so as to have maximum effect on employment and growth.

(ii) It is proposed that as part of the programme of preparation for the millennium, the council should prepare, by end of 1996, a series of reports outlining the economic, social and demographic profile of Ireland in the year 2000 and beyond. This forms part of its work on Ireland in the 21st century. The council is asked to explore the possibility that the Northern Ireland Economic Council would join in this analysis on either an integrated or complementary basis.

(iii) When the Taoiseach visited the council in January he requested it to prepare a strategy document as an input to the negotiation of a new national programme to cover the years 1997, 1998 and 1999. In this context the Taoiseach asked the NESC to examine the role partnership at the firm level had to play in creating the basis for the constructive and flexible response necessary from the Irish economy to European Monetary Union and the effect of currency movements outside the European Monetary Union on particular sectors and firms within the economy.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. O'Rourke Mrs. O'Rourke
Speaker.P: It is obvious that the NESC will be busy. I thank the Minister of State for his comprehensive reply but will he say what progress has been made in the talks on another programme or whether firm talks must await the outcome of these momentous and monumental studies?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: The Taoiseach and the Minister for Finance indicated that the Government favours the continuation of these talks. I am not aware that a date has been set for firm talks but ongoing meetings have taken place between the social partners and the Government at various levels. It is the Government's hope that such talks will take place and that a further agreement can be negotiated provided the terms can be agreed by all concerned.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. McDowell Mr. M. McDowell
Speaker.P: Did the Minister of State say the NESC has been asked to prepare a report on the implementation of the Moriarty report on the implementation of the Culliton report?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: The report sought from the NESC will assist the Government in the implementation of these reports.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cullen Mr. Cullen
Speaker.P: Will the Minister agree there is no longer a necessity for reports given that the Government has not implemented any of the recommendations made in previous reports? The OECD report gave examples of the difficulties caused in the economy by over expenditure and too high personal tax rates. Will the Minister agree that if those issues were tackled by the Government there would be no need for these elaborate reports and some serious work could be done?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Creed Mr. Creed
Speaker.P: Why did the Deputy's party not tackle these issues when it was in Government?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: I do not accept that point. The NESC has also been asked to look at various European reports, not least the report on competitiveness——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cullen Mr. Cullen
Speaker.P: I was referring to the other reports referred to by the Minister of State.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: We need its analysis on the implications for Ireland of these important reports and also its advice on their implementation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cullen Mr. Cullen
Speaker.P: There is so much analysis that we do not know where we are going.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. McDowell Mr. M. McDowell
Speaker.P: Paralysis by analysis.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. O'Rourke Mrs. O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Will the Minister of State, the Taoiseach or members of their party have difficulty in going down the consensus path of national agreements given their rabid denunciation of them in Dáil Éireann on a previous occasion?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: This House is made up of different parties with different views.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. O'Rourke Mrs. O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I am asking about the Minister's party.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: The process of Government is not about assimilation but about integration. The Government will express its views as a Government.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Strategic Management Initiative.

Qst.Quest: the steps, if any, that have been taken to implement the Strategic Management Initiative.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: Implementation of the Strategic Management Initiative is well under way, both at the level of the individual Departments and offices and, centrally, through Government consideration of an overall programme of change in the public service. Preliminary statements of strategy are now being revised and finalised. Statements will be published for all Departments and offices during this year. The SMI will be extended to the wider public service during 1996. I understand that my colleague, the Minister for the Environment, is launching the SMI to local authorities later this month.

The second report to Government of the co-ordinating group of secretaries, established under the Strategic Management Initiative, setting out a comprehensive framework for change, has now been completed. The Government will announce in the near future a comprehensive programme for reform of the public service. This programme comprises a number of initiatives within an overall framework setting out a strategic direction for the future. The initiatives will address a number of matters such as greater delegation and devolution and improved accountability within the Civil Service, improvements in service quality and delivery, regulatory reform, better co-ordination across Departments and improved personnel and financial management systems.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. O'Rourke Mrs. O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Does the Minister foresee any difficulty in promulgating the Strategic Management Initiative in view of the way the Civil Service has been treated by the Minister for Finance, who has responsibility for the public service?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: Following discussions with the Dáil Select Committee on Finance and General Affairs, it is hoped that, at a stage appropriate to the publication, the Opposition parties will be briefed on the content. Detailed consultations will be held with the relevant unions regarding the implementation of the reform process.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Woods Dr. Woods
Speaker.P: Is it the Government's intention to publish the individual strategic management initiatives for particular Departments and, if so, when will they be published? In some Departments the initiatives have been implemented since the end of 1994. Is it not important to inform the House and the public of these initiatives?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: I do not have any objection in principle. If there are any difficulties in practice I will have to reserve the Government's position on this. When the Government's public service reform proposals are put forward, which will probably be in May, all these matters will be for public debate. There will be a great deal of initiatives and worthwhile reform resulting from the process.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Woods Dr. Woods
Speaker.P: The strategic management initiative for any one Department is a major document. It is important for the development of that Department, the economy and the country. I am not asking about the global initiative which will contain a little of everything but the initiatives for particular Departments. The initiative for the Department of Social Welfare is completed and I have a copy. When will the Government publish them so that the public can see where Departments are going?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: This is clearly repetition.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Woods Dr. Woods
Speaker.P: No, it is not. It is a specific question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: I estimate that the launch of the document will take place in May. If there are no difficulties in practice, the individual documents will also be released. I have to reserve my position on this because some Departments deal with important security matters. The matter needs to be considered on a Department by Department basis.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cullen Mr. Cullen
Speaker.P: Has any progress been made on opening the closed door policy which exists for members of professional bodies within the Civil Service who are disbarred from seeking promotion? I have raised this on numerous occasions.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: The Deputy is raising a new matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: That is a separate question and can be addressed in the debate following publication of the Government's proposals.

Qst.Quest: the additional departmental responsibilities he has acquired, or existing ones that have been passed to another Department since he took office other than those announced in December 1994.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: The two existing functions transferred in respect of the Department since the Taoiseach came into office are community employment in designated partnership areas, responsibility for which was transferred to the Department of Enterprise and Employment under a transfer of functions order on 6 February 1996, and access to the offshore islands which is now the responsibility of the Minister of State, Deputy Carey. Arrangements are being put in place to transfer functions under the Aran Islands Transport Act, 1946, from the Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications to the Minister of State, Deputy Carey.

In addition, my Department has acquired responsibility for the following new functions: the Devolution Commission for Local Government Reform, established in July 1995; the development of a national anti-poverty strategy, in association with the Department of Social Welfare, in line with the commitment given at the UN Social Summit in Copenhagen; a review of the administration of development programmes in the Border counties, with a view to maximising their effectiveness; and responsibility for co-funding those parts of the EU programme for peace and reconciliation for which ADM has been designated as the intermediary.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Special Co-operation Initiatives.

Qst.Quest: the special co-operation initiatives, if any, that were undertaken by his Department in 1995; and the initiatives, if any, that are proposed for 1996.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: My Department has undertaken one initiative under subhead D2 — special co-operation initiatives — in 1995. This initiative is the Irish Genealogical Project which is an all-Ireland, tourism project arising from the work of the Task Force on Roots, Genealogy and Tourism.

The Irish Genealogical Project has brought together all those, North and South of the island of Ireland, involved in genealogy and provides the means by which those concerned can contribute to developing genealogy in its own right but also in its capacity as a tourism attraction.

The primary focus of the project is the generation of visitor traffic to Ireland which has been motivated by the appeal in tracing roots, and as a consequence of this, the creation of jobs and employment opportunities in the tourism and travel sectors. The project is designed to improve dramatically genealogical research facilities to the point where they can be marketed to tourists of Irish descent all over the world.

MainHeading.P: This is to be achieved through the creation of a family history research service, based on locally created and controlled databases. There are some 35 genealogical centres now spread throughout the Thirty-two Counties where computerisation of records from parish records and other sources is almost complete.

The project has both national and local economic benefits, through the development of community based initiatives and training and skills development. The employment potential, both direct and indirect, of the project, when successfully developed and marketed, will be considerable.

In addition to the economic benefits the project has proven that it can foster several worthwhile social benefits, including all-Ireland cross-community relations, local community awareness and pride in local heritage.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. O'Rourke Mrs. O'Rourke
